Award.AwardTitle: The Nuclear Role of the Plant Cell Death Suppressor Adi3

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit: Programmed cell death is an essential process for development and immune responses in most organisms. In plants this process plays a role in leaf senescence, development of xylem tracheary elements, and host responses to pathogens. Relatively few plant genes have been identified that have a direct role in the signal transduction pathway that leads to programmed cell death. The investigator discovered the Adi3 kinase in tomato that appears to be a central component of the pathway that controls the suppression of programmed cell death. Adi3 protein localizes to the nucleus of the plant cell; but, the precise mechanism of how this protein functions is unknown. The investigator postulates that Adi3 interacts with specific nuclear proteins. This project is designed to identify and characterize these interactors using sophisticated proteomics and computational approaches to simulate and reconstruct the network of the Adi3-specific signaling pathway.
Broader Impacts: Understanding how plants suppress cell death in most cellular functions, and allow the cell death to occur during senescence, xylem maturation, and protection from pathogen infection, is a very important question and has obvious potential benefits for agriculture. The integrated research and educational activities will provide training and educational opportunities for students to gain multi-disciplinary training in how to solve complex biological questions through iterations of experimentation and theory.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Plants utilize the process known as programmed cell death (PCD) during developmental processes and as a mechanism to defend against pathogen attack. In PCD, plant cells are killed in order to achieve the needed outcome. For example, when bacterial pathogens attack a plant the plant cells that are attacked are killed by PCD in order to prevent further spread of the pathogen. In plants not much is known about how PCD is controlled and regulated. This project was focused on identifying mechanisms in tomato plants for controlling PCD in response to pathogen attack. By further understanding plant PCD the data generated from this study could help to generate plants that are longer lived or more resistant to pathogens, and thus are able to produce more products such as grain, fruits, or vegetables. We previously identified the tomato protein called Adi3 that controls PCD for providing resistance to the bacteria that causes to tomato disease known as bacterial speck disease. Our goals for this project were to identify other proteins that interact with Adi3 to help it control PCD for resistance to this bacteria. We were able to identify several proteins that potentially interact with Adi3 for this purpose. Follow up studies will determine the specific role of these proteins in controlling PCD in coordination with Adi3. These studies will allow scientists to produce more productive or healthy plants, which will greatly benefit society in general through the production of more and healthier food for society.
